sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Veilrot is a dark skirmish miniatures game set in a world unraveling at the seams—reshaped by the irradiant remnants of a shattered moon. When that celestial body fractured, it bled something divine and ruinous into the soil.

Now, reality itself is in flux. Fungal intelligences bloom beneath the surface, faith burns in silver fire, and ancient technologies twitch back to life. Nothing is stable. Nothing is safe. Nothing is sacred.

Players command warbands—small, elite groups of warriors, zealots, constructs, or aberrations—each shaped by their beliefs, biology, and battle doctrine. Some seek to restore what was lost, others to profit from the collapse, and still others to accelerate the transformation of the world into something wholly alien.

Gameplay in Veilrot focuses on tactical decision-making, resourceful positioning, and risk-driven combat. Every choice—whether movement, attack, or objective play—can swing the course of a game. There are no large armies here, only small forces with outsized impact, fighting over relics, memories, and fragments of power.

Factions are distinct in both theme and mechanics, but all warbands operate within the same brutal framework of conflict. Combat is fast and unforgiving. Objectives matter. Momentum shifts quickly. And the battlefield is never neutral—it twists and reacts with its own ancient hungers.

This document introduces the core mechanics that define how Veilrot is played. It covers everything from turn structure and actions to combat, objectives, and mission creation. Whether you come to burn, bind, or break the world, the first step is understanding its rules.

sections.title: What You Need to Play
sections.content:
To play a game of Veilrot, each player will need to bring the tools of war, fate, and ruin. These essentials shape the battlefield and ensure smooth play:

  • A Warband: Each player commands a small group of unique miniatures, known as a warband. These may be custom-built or selected from pre-made rosters, and should include figure sheets, condition markers, and any relevant faction tokens or relic counters.
  • Measuring Tools: Movement and range in Veilrot are measured in inches. A ruler or tape measure marked in inches is required for all gameplay.
  • Six-sided Dice (D6): All rolls in Veilrot use standard six-sided dice. It's recommended that each player have a handful for attack rolls, saves, Grit checks, and other effects.
  • Rulebook & Reference Sheets: Having the Veilrot Core Rules and faction-specific references on hand helps resolve abilities, conditions, and combat triggers without slowing the game.
  • A Battlefield: Games of Veilrot are played on a richly textured battlefield, filled with ruins, fungal overgrowth, broken trenches, and unnatural terrain. The standard play area is 3 feet by 3 feet. Scenarios may adjust this size for narrative reasons. Objective markers—used to represent key control points or relics—should be included as part of the terrain setup.

Creating an evocative battlefield enhances immersion and supports the game's focus on movement, line of sight, and area control.

sections.title: Core Concepts
sections.content: Before learning the flow of a turn, it helps to understand a few key principles that apply throughout the game. These are the foundations of how models interact, measure, and resolve actions in Veilrot.

sections.title: Rolling Dice
sections.content:
All checks in the game use standard six-sided dice (D6). When a rule says to roll, it usually means: roll one or more dice and compare each result to a target number (like "4+," meaning you need a 4 or higher to succeed).

Sometimes you'll see the term natural roll. This means the number showing on the die before any modifiers are added.

  • A natural 1 always fails, even if you have bonuses.
  • A natural 6 always succeeds, no matter the odds.
  • Modifiers (like +1 to Hit) are added to the roll after the roll is made.

sections.title: Line of Sight
sections.content:
To see if a model can target something—like for a ranged attack or ability—you check line of sight. That simply means: can the model see the target?

You can measure this from any point on the model's body or its base. If any part of the target is visible from that perspective (even just an arm or weapon), line of sight is clear. Obstructions like walls or terrain might block it.

sections.title: Measuring Distance
sections.content: All distances—movement, range, abilities—are measured from the edge of one model's base to another. Always base to base.

sections.title: Rounding & Fractals
sections.content:
In Veilrot, you'll never need fractions or decimals. All measurements, calculations, and effects are handled in whole numbers.

If a rule or effect results in a partial number—like 2.5 Wounds or 3.3 inches—always round up to the nearest whole number, unless a rule specifically says otherwise.

Example: A model falls 2.3 inches. That becomes 3" for the purpose of fall damage. Another ability inflicts 1.5 Wounds—this becomes 2.

sections.title: Engagement Range
sections.content:
A model is engaged when it's within 1" of an enemy. Engagement matters because:

  • You can't Move, Dash, or Charge while engaged.
  • You can't make Ranged Attacks or use Special Actions unless a rule says you can.
  • You can still make Melee Attacks, or try to Disengage.

Once you understand these basics, the rest of the game flows much more easily. Keep them in mind—they come up often.

sections.title: Keywords
sections.content:
Throughout the rules, certain words appear in bold italics—these are keywords. They act as flags that describe a model's traits, affiliations, or special rules. Keywords don't have rules by themselves, but other abilities and effects may refer to them.

For example, an ability might say, "Target one friendly model with the Relic-bound keyword," or, "This effect cannot target Spectral enemies."

Most models have multiple keywords, drawn from their faction, role, or physiology. Some common keyword types include:

  • Faction (e.g. Moonfall, Thornbound, Carrion Emissaries)
  • Type (e.g. Leader, Anchor, Relic-bound, Construct, Infantry, Squad)
  • Status or Nature (e.g. Bloomed, Spectral, Aberrant, Solo)

If a rule requires a specific keyword, only models with that exact term are affected. Keywords are always capitalized and appear in a unit's datasheet for easy reference.

sections.title: Tokens
sections.content:
Tokens are small counters used to track temporary effects, abilities, or game states. These can represent anything from buffs and debuffs to faction-specific mechanics like charges, corruption, or vows.

Tokens are not models and cannot be targeted or interacted with unless a rule specifically allows it. They are placed on or near models, objectives, or the battlefield to show ongoing effects.

Common uses for tokens include:
  • Status effects (e.g. Burning, Stunned, Bound)
  • Faction mechanics (e.g. Vestigial Remnants, Correction Counters)
  • Ability tracking (e.g. once-per-round triggers or delayed effects)
  • Objective control or scoring markers

If a token with a keyword is placed next to a model, that model is considered to have that keyword for as long as the token remains in play. This allows abilities, effects, or interactions to reference the keyword as if it were part of the model's own profile.

Tokens should be clearly identifiable and removed when their effect ends. You can use custom counters, dice, or even scraps—as long as both players agree on what they represent.

sections.title: Markers
sections.content:
Markers are physical objects placed on the battlefield to represent important locations or scenario elements. Unlike tokens, which track effects, markers define spaces—such as relic sites, control points, or mission targets.

All Markers in Veilrot are placed on a 32mm base. This ensures consistent measurements and interaction across missions and abilities.

Markers may include:
  • Objective Markers — Used for scoring, contesting, and control (Primary or Secondary)
  • Offering Sites — Used in missions like Offering Grounds
  • Mission-Specific Elements — Such as sigil sites, charged relics, or pulse emitters

Unless a rule says otherwise, measure all distances from the edge of the marker's base. Some markers may have special rules for interaction, destruction, or movement—always refer to the mission's instructions.

sections.title: Counters
sections.content: <em>

Counters are objects placed off the battlefield, used to track resources, limited-use abilities, or faction mechanics.

They represent things like Ashfragments, Relic charges, or Overwatch uses.
Counters are typically placed beside a player's reference sheet, warband card, or token pool.
Some rules allow players to spend, gain, or convert counters during the game.
Counters have no physical presence on the battlefield and cannot be targeted or interacted with by enemies.

Use any clear marker (dice, coins, symbols) that both players agree upon.

sections.title: Turn Sequence
sections.content:
Veilrot is played in alternating activations, which means players take turns activating one figure at a time instead of controlling their entire warband in one go. This system keeps the gameplay dynamic and interactive, forcing players to respond to evolving battlefield conditions.

Each game round is divided into three distinct phases:

sections.title: Initiative Phase
sections.content: At the start of each round, both players count the number of models in their warband currently on the battlefield. Then, each rolls a D6. The player with the highest result wins the initiative and chooses whether to activate a figure first or allow their opponent to do so. This choice can be critical—sometimes it's better to wait and react, while other times seizing the initiative can swing the tide of battle.

sections.title: Action Phase
sections.content:
Players then take turns activating their figures one at a time. When a figure activates, it can perform up to two actions, such as moving, attacking, or using a special ability. Figures cannot perform the same action twice in a single activation unless specifically allowed by a rule. Once a figure has completed its activation, it cannot act again that round. This continues until all figures from both sides have activated.

This alternating system encourages tactical foresight—players must weigh the risks of leaving figures vulnerable versus capitalizing on opportfigureies as they arise.

sections.title: End Phase
sections.content: After all figures have activated, the End Phase begins. During this phase, players resolve any lingering effects such as ongoing conditions, scenario triggers, or end-of-round objective scoring. It's also a moment to assess the battlefield and prepare for the next round of conflict.

sections.title: Figure Activation
sections.content:
When a figure activates, it may perform up to two actions. These actions represent everything from careful positioning to brutal combat or strategic ability use. Unless a rule specifically says otherwise, a figure cannot perform the same action twice in a single activation.

Here are the most common actions a figure can take:

sections.title: Move
sections.content:
The figure travels up to its Movement (M) value in inches across the battlefield. This action is often used to reposition, advance toward objectives, or retreat from threats. Movement is affected by terrain and elevation as described in the Movement rules.

A figure cannot end a Move action within 1" of an enemy model.
A figure also cannot perform a Move action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Dash
sections.content:
The figure surges forward in a desperate sprint. Roll a D6 and add the result to the figure's Movement value for this action. However, a figure that Dashes cannot Attack or Charge in the same activation. Dash is ideal for repositioning, escaping danger, or reaching objectives.

A figure cannot Dash while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Charge
sections.content:
Charging is the bold act of hurling a figure into close combat, often turning the tide of battle with momentum and force. To declare a charge, first select one or more enemy models within line of sight as your target. Then roll 1D6 and add the result to your figure's Movement (M) value—this total is your charge distance.

If the target is within that distance to the target, move the charging figure toward them, placing it into engagement range (1"). Because of the momentum and aggression behind the charge, the attacker gains +1 to Hit on any subsequent attacks this activation.

If the distance rolled isn't enough to reach the target, the charge fails—the figure remains in place and the action is wasted.

Some weapons and abilities gain bonuses when charging, so always check your figure's traits and gear. A well-timed charge can overwhelm defenses and seize control of contested ground—just be sure the distance isn't too great, or your warriors may fall short and exposed.

Note: A charging figure may not end its movement within engagement range of any enemy model other than its declared targets, following the same restrictions as normal movement.

sections.title: Attack
sections.content:
The figure makes a melee or ranged attack with one of its equipped weapons. Melee attacks require the target to be within engagement range, while ranged attacks must respect line of sight and range bands. Each attack follows the core Hit → Save → Damage → Grit sequence, as described in the combat rules.

A figure cannot make a ranged Attack while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Retaliate
sections.content: <em>

This model may spend one action during its activation to enter a retaliatory stance. When it does, place a Retaliate token next to it.

If the model is targeted by an attack and survives, you may remove the Retaliate token to make an immediate free attack back against the attacker (melee or ranged, as appropriate).

Only one Retaliate token may be active on a model at a time.

This effect can only trigger once per round, and is lost if the token is not used by the end of the round.

sections.title: Disengage
sections.content:
This action allows a figure to carefully withdraw from close combat. The model may move up to its full Movement value away from any enemy models it is engaged with, so long as this movement ends outside of engagement range of any enemy models.

A figure that performs a Disengage action cannot Move, Attack, Dash, Charge, or use a Special Action for the remainder of its activation.

sections.title: Stand Up
sections.content: Any model that is Prone may use one of its actions to stand up. This removes the Prone condition. Standing up costs effort. Timing it well is key—do you risk standing while vulnerable, or wait for support to arrive?

sections.title: Cover
sections.content:
The figure braces for incoming fire or hunkers behind the environment. This action may only be taken if the model is within 1" of a terrain feature.

While under the effect of Cover, if the model is Obscured by that terrain feature when attacked, the attacker suffers an additional –1 to Hit. The effect lasts until the figure's next activation or until it moves.

A figure cannot take the Cover action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Special Action
sections.content:
Many figures have unique abilities, rituals, or technological tricks listed in their rules. These often take the form of Special Actions and can include anything from healing allies to manipulating objectives or terrain.

A figure cannot perform a Special action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Overreach
sections.content: <em>

A model may attempt a third action during its activation. This is called an Overreach, and the action taken may be one the model has already performed this turn.

Roll 1D6. On a 3+, the action succeeds and resolves as normal.
On a 1–2, the Overreach fails and the activation ends immediately.

If it fails:
  • The opponent chooses any model on the battlefield (friendly or enemy) that has not yet activated. That model must activate immediately.
  • After that activation, turns proceed as normal.


The Overreaching model suffers the following penalties until the start of your next turn:
  • Its Claim is reduced to 0
  • All attacks targeting it may reroll failed Hit rolls


Understanding which combination of actions best suits a situation is the heart of Veilrot's tactical depth. Whether you push forward aggressively, hold your ground, or use battlefield manipulation, how you spend each activation defines your warband's success.

sections.title: Movement & Terrain
sections.content:
Movement in Veilrot is measured in inches and is one of the most tactically important parts of the game. A figure's Movement (M) stat defines how far it may travel when performing a Move or Charge action.

Models move freely across open ground, but terrain and elevation introduce key restrictions and opportunities.

Figures cannot move through other models unless they have a special rule that allows it. Likewise, most models may not end their movement overlapping another base, on impassable terrain, or in mid-air.

sections.title: Terrain Effects
sections.content:
Difficult terrain, such as rubble, thick fungus, or waterlogged ground, costs double movement to cross.

For example, moving 2 inches through difficult terrain would cost 4 inches of movement. Figures can still move out of or around such terrain if they have the remaining movement to do so.

Vertical movement, such as climbing up walls or over obstacles, also costs double movement. Additionally, a model cannot move more than 3 inches vertically in a single direction during a single activation, unless it has a rule or equipment that states otherwise.

A model may not end its movement while partway through vertical traversal; it must fully complete the vertical move or remain where it started.

This creates meaningful decision-making when traversing multi-level battlefields and rewards strategic use of terrain, ladders, and elevation rules. Some warbands or figures may possess special rules to ignore or reduce these movement penalties, making them especially mobile or evasive in ruined environments.

sections.title: Fall
sections.content:
Sometimes a model ends up somewhere it didn't mean to be—knocked from a ledge, pulled by an ability, or simply misjudging a drop. In Veilrot, falling hurts.

Whenever a model falls from a height, it suffers 1 point of damage for each full inch fallen, minus its Strength stat.

• Only full inches count—round down if needed
• This damage can't be blocked by Save rolls
• However, the model still rolls Grit checks as normal to try and resist the incoming harm

Example: A model with Strength 3 falls 5". It takes 2 damage (5 – 3 = 2). It then rolls 2 Grit checks—one for each point of damage.

If the Strength value is equal to or greater than the fall distance, the model hits the ground hard but uninjured. You can imagine it rolling with the impact, digging into the terrain, or simply being built to survive worse.

A model taking damage in this way is also knocked Prone.

sections.title: Prone
sections.content:
A model that becomes Prone has been knocked off its feet, staggered to the ground, or otherwise thrown out of fighting stance. This condition limits the model's options severely until it recovers.

While Prone:
  • The model can't perform any actions other than Stand Up
  • It can still be targeted by attacks and abilities
  • It counts as Engaged if within 1" of an enemy, but cannot make Melee Attacks until it recovers

Being Prone represents loss of footing, momentary collapse, or being driven to the ground by force. It's dangerous to stay that way—especially near enemies.

sections.title: Collide
sections.content:
Sometimes, a model is shoved, hurled, dragged, or launched—and ends up crashing into something else. In Veilrot, when a moving model involuntarily collides with another model, the result is often bruising, bone-snapping, or worse.

A collision occurs when a model is forced to move and ends its movement overlapping the base of another model. This can happen from knockback effects, pull abilities, terrain shifts, or being flung by explosions or relic effects.

When a collision occurs:
Both models suffers Wounds equal to:
[enemy model's Toughness] + [distance moved] – [its own Toughness]

sections.title: Combat
sections.content:
Combat in Veilrot is intense, personal, and layered. It's not just about who swings first or who wears thicker armor—it's about positioning, momentum, and the desperate edge between life and death.

Every time a model makes an attack, it unfolds in two linked stages: the Clash, where weapons meet resistance, and the Suffering, where consequences take root.

Understanding this sequence—what it tests, what it rewards—is key to mastering the battlefield.

sections.title: Clash
sections.content:
The moment of impact—when attacks are made and resisted.

This is the exchange of blows: the moment steel meets flesh, or thought meets entropy. In Clash, both attacker and defender engage in opposed rolls that determine if the attack lands and whether it can be turned aside. This phase includes to-hit rolls, saves, and any resulting triggers—such as critical strikes, flawless hits, or disastrous fumbles. It's fast, volatile, and often decisive.

Roll to Hit:
To begin, the attacker rolls a number of D6 equal to their weapon's Attack Dice. Each roll is compared to the attacker's Strike (for melee) or Aim (for ranged). If the modified result is equal to or greater than that stat, the die is a hit.

Modifiers (such as charging, terrain, or effects) are added to the roll itself, not to the target number.

Example: If a model has Strike 4+ and rolls a 3, but has a +1 bonus from charging, the final result is a 4—so it counts as a hit.

Roll to Save:
For each hit scored, the defender rolls one D6 and compares each result to their Save value, which is determined by the armor or shield they are using. A roll that meets or exceeds the Save value is a success.

Save modifiers (such as from a weapon's profile) are also added to the roll, not subtracted from the Save value.

Example: If a defender has Save 4+ and the attacker's weapon has a –1 Save Modifier, the defender must roll a 5. But instead of changing the target number, you simply add –1 to the roll. So a rolled 5 becomes a 4—just enough to save.

sections.title: Suffering
sections.content:
Now comes the cost—the pain inflicted, and the will to survive it.

Once an attack breaches defenses, Suffering determines the toll. Damage is calculated based on the attacker's Strength versus the defender's Toughness, then blunted—or not—by raw resolve. This phase reveals the aftermath: the wounds dealt, the Grit tested, and the line between survival and collapse.

Apply Damage:
If at least one save failed, the attack deals damage. The weapon's base Damage is listed on its profile, but this amount can be multiplied depending on how hard the blow landed.

First, for each unsaved hit, the attacker rolls one D6—this is a Damage Roll. Modifiers are applied to the roll result, based on how the attacker's Strength compares to the target's Toughness.

Strength vs Toughness ComparisonModifier to Damage Roll
Strength is greater than Toughness+1
Strength is at least double Toughness+2
Strength is lower than Toughness–1
Strength is half or less than Toughness–2


Once the modifiers are applied, take the highest of all Damage Rolls from that attack. Only that result is used to determine how much damage is inflicted—representing the most punishing strike landing cleanly.

• On a 5+, the damage is doubled
• On a 7+, the damage is tripled

Example: You roll 3 Damage Dice and get 4, 5, and 6. After modifiers, they become 5, 6, and 7. The 7+ triples the damage. If the weapon has Damage 2, the final result is 6 damage.

Grit Check:
Once the damage is set, the defender rolls a Grit Check for each point of damage taken. For each damage, roll one D6. If the result equals or exceeds the model's Grit value, that point of damage is negated.

This is the final layer of survival. Grit doesn't represent physical armor—it reflects willpower, resolve, mutation, or sheer refusal to fall.

Example: A figure takes 4 damage and has Grit 5+. It rolls 4 dice: 5, 2, 6, 3. Two results are 5 or more, so only 2 damage is suffered.

sections.title: Damage from other sources
sections.content: Even outside of attacks, figures may roll Grit checks against any source of damage—whether from abilities, terrain, or mission effects. For each point taken, roll one D6: results equal to or above the figure's Grit negate that damage. Grit always applies, reflecting raw endurance in any situation.

sections.title: Triggers
sections.content:
After rolling for either hit, save or grit, check for special triggers:
  • Critical: Any die that rolls a natural 6 is considered a Critical and may trigger abilities or effects.
  • Flawless: All dice hit. Some weapons or abilities gain bonuses when this occurs.
  • Fumble: All dice miss. This can trigger penalties or setbacks.
These triggers represent either moments of uncanny precision or devastating failure, and often tie into a weapon's traits or a figure's special rules.

sections.title: Survivor's Surge
sections.content:
If a model rolls a Grit check with 3 or more dice, and all rolls succeed, it may immediately do one of the following:
  • Make a free melee or ranged attack against the attacking model
  • Move up to 3" (ignoring engagement range, but not terrain)
This only triggers if the model survives the damage after the Grit check.
This free action does not cost an action and does not trigger other abilities (like charge bonuses).

sections.title: Combat Example
sections.content:
The Thornbound Choir Warrior declares a charge against the Bastion Concord Soldier.
The distance between them is 8".
The Warrior has a Movement of 5" and rolls a 4 for the charge.
With a total of 9", the charge succeeds.
He moves into Engagement Range of his target.


As his second action he attacks with his Short Sword (4 dice):
With Strike 4+, he rolls and scores 3 hits—one of them a Critical.


Now it's the Bastion Concord's turn to make saves:
He rolls 3 dice—one for each hit from the attack.
His Heavy Leather gives a 4+ Save normally.
But the attack's Critical hit worsens it to a 5+.
He rolls the dice—only one is a success.


The Bastion Concord failed two saves.
The Thornbound Warrior now rolls for damage.
Strength and Toughness are equal, so no modifier.
He rolls a 4 and a 5, and takes the highest result.
A 5 means double damage is dealt!
The Short Sword deals 1 damage—doubled to 2.


As a final step, the Bastion Concord makes Grit checks:
He rolls one die for each point of damage taken.
His Grit is 5+, so he needs 5 or higher to cancel.
He rolls a 1 and a 6—one success.
One point of damage is cancelled, one goes through.

sections.title: Common Abilities
sections.content:
Combat in Veilrot is intense, personal, and layered. It's not just about who swings first or who wears thicker armor—it's about positioning, momentum, and the desperate edge between life and death.

Every time a model makes an attack, it unfolds in two linked stages: the Clash, where weapons meet resistance, and the Suffering, where consequences take root.

Understanding this sequence—what it tests, what it rewards—is key to mastering the battlefield.

sections.title: Last Stand (X+)
sections.content:
Once per battle, when this model's Wounds are reduced to 0, roll a D6. On a result of 5 or higher, it survives the attack sequence with 1 Wound remaining.
Triggers after Grit checks, before the model is removed.
Only works once per battle.

sections.title: Guarded
sections.content:
When an enemy allocates hit rolls to this model, you may choose to redirect all of them to a single friendly model within 2".
Declare this before any Save rolls are made.
You must redirect all hits—you can't split them between models.
This lets nearby allies step in and take the hit—whether through duty, desperation, or design.

sections.title: Brutal Impact (X+)
sections.content: After completing a Charge, roll 4D6 against a target of the charge. Each roll of X or higher deals 1 damage.

sections.title: Bloodthirsty
sections.content: After this model kills a target in melee, it may immediately make a melee attack against another enemy in engagement range.

sections.title: Anchored
sections.content: This model cannot be pushed, pulled, or moved by enemy effects unless explicitly stated. It also cannot be displaced by terrain shifts, forced movement, or objective interactions unless specified.

sections.title: Honed Reflex
sections.content: This model may make a ranged attack even after performing a Dash during the same activation. The attack suffers –1 to Hit unless the weapon has the Balanced or Light trait.

sections.title: Frenzied Rush
sections.content: This model may declare a Charge even after performing a Dash during the same activation. If the Dash added 4" or more, it gains +1 Attack Dice on its first melee attack that activation.

sections.title: Iron Grasp
sections.content: <em>

This model may treat two-handed weapons as one-handed for all purposes.
It may equip a second item in the off-hand, such as a shield or another weapon.
It does not reduce the weapon's Strength, Damage, or any other stats.
The model must still meet any other restrictions for equipping the weapon.
This ability has no effect on ranged weapons unless otherwise stated.

sections.title: The Figure Datasheet
sections.content: Each figure in Veilrot is represented by a datasheet that contains all the information needed to use that model in the game. The datasheet includes the model's characteristics, weapons, abilities, and any special rules that apply to it.

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Equipment represents the weapons, armor, and other gear that your figures can use in battle. Each piece of equipment has specific rules and characteristics that affect how it can be used.

sections.title: Melee Weapons
sections.content: Melee weapons are used in close combat. Each weapon has characteristics such as Attack Dice, Strength, Damage, and special traits that define how it performs in battle.

sections.title: Range Weapons
sections.content: Ranged weapons allow figures to attack from a distance. They have characteristics like Range, Attack Dice, Strength, Damage, and special traits that determine their effectiveness.

sections.title: Shields
sections.content: Shields provide defensive bonuses and can be used to protect figures from incoming attacks. They often grant Save bonuses and may have special defensive abilities.

sections.title: Armor
sections.content: Armor provides protection against damage. Different types of armor offer varying levels of protection through Save bonuses and may have special defensive traits.

sections.title: Generate Mission Rules
sections.content:
Generate Mission Rules
With the battlefield and deployment zones established, it's time to determine what your warbands are
fighting over. This stage defines the heart of the scenario—what must be claimed, protected, or destroyed to
achieve victory.
The first part of this process is placing Objective Markers.
Place Objective Markers
Objective markers represent relics, control points, corrupted growths, or sites of tactical value. These can
influence the flow of battle dramatically, creating focal points that demand attention and draw blood.
To determine how many objective markers are placed and where they are located, roll 1D6 and consult the
Objective Marker Table. This roll determines the type and layout of objectives for the scenario. Some
results may create a single focal point; others may scatter multiple smaller objectives across the board.
This method ensures that each game feels different, with terrain, deployment, and objectives combining in
unique ways to shape the strategies both players will need to adopt.

Once you have your result, place the objective markers as described—usually at set distances from the center
or corners of the board. Be sure to place them before any models are deployed.
After objective markers are placed, players can then determine the mission's Primary Objective and any
Secondary Objectives that will be in play. These objectives define how players earn points or claim victory
and are influenced by the positioning of the markers already on the board.

sections.title: How to Generate a Player Objective
sections.content:
How to Generate a Player Objective
1. After the mission is selected but before deployment, each player rolls 1D6:
○ On a 1–3, roll on Table A: Tactical Objectives.
○ On a 4–6, roll on Table B: Strike Objectives.
2. Then roll 1D6 again to determine your objective from the chosen table.
3. Keep the result secret until it is completed or revealed at the end of the game.
You may only complete one Player Objective per battle. Each one has its own listed Victory Point
reward.

sections.title: Table A: Tactical Objectives
sections.content:
Table A: Tactical Objectives
1. Line Breaker — 3 Victory Point
Control three different objectives in the same round.
Success requires timing and bold positioning to claim multiple zones at once.
2. Zone Denial — 3 Victory Points
Control three different objectives at the end of the game.
This long-term goal rewards strategic resilience and endgame control.
3. Sigil Claimant — 3 Victory Point
Perform the Claim Sigil action on an objective. This Player Objective can be achieved more than once, but
only once for each objective on the battlefield.
This action represents your warband marking an objective site for unknown purposes.
Claim Sigil (Action): While controlling an objective, a model may perform this action on an
objective they are contesting.
4. Hold the Line — 3 Victory Point
At the end of the game, at least half of your starting models must remain alive on the battlefield.
Simple, but challenging in brutal scenarios.
5. Oppressive Advance — 3 Victory Point
At any point during the game, have at least one model contesting every Primary Objective.
You don't need to control them—just be within 1".
6. Commanding Presence — 3 Victory Point
Have your Leader contest a controlled Primary Objective at the end of any round.
Assert dominance through leadership and placement.
50

sections.title: Table B: Strike Objectives
sections.content:
Table B: Strike Objectives
1. Wipe the Blade — 3 Victory Point
Destroy four enemy figures during the game.
A steady and relentless approach to battlefield elimination.
2. Break the Chain — 3 Victory Points
Destroy the enemy Leader model.
High risk, high reward—requires precise execution or raw power.
3. Precision Execution — 3 Victory Points
Destroy two enemy figures while also scoring at least one critical hit.
You must deliver the killing blow in an attack that includes at least one 6 on the Hit roll.
4. First to Spill — 3 Victory Point
Be the first player to destroy an enemy figure.
If your opponent scores the first kill, this objective cannot be completed.
5. No Witnesses — 3 Victory Points
At the end of the game, no enemy figures may be within 6" of your deployment zone.
Defend your territory and deny your opponent infiltration.
6. Strike and Fade — 3 Victory Points
In a single round, destroy an enemy figure and then move the attacker 5" or more away from the site of the
kill.
Mobility and precision define this surgical goal.

51

Narrative Layers (Optional)
Every battlefield in Veilrot tells a story. Some whisper in fungal breath, others scream with silver flame or
machine static. While the mission defines how victory is measured, the narrative layer defines what the battle
feels like—and what's truly at stake.

sections.title: Using a Narrative Layer
sections.content:
Using a Narrative Layer
Before defining the mission and battlefield, players may choose to add a Narrative Layer to their battle.
This step is entirely optional and doesn't affect gameplay rules, but it provides rich flavor, deeper immersion,
and inspiration for terrain, model behavior, and storytelling. It can also help with visualizing and
encapsulating the setting around the conflict.
To generate one randomly:
1. Roll 1D6 to determine which category of battlefield you're fighting on.
D6 Roll
Narrative Layer Category
1–2
Sacred & Profaned Sites
3–4
Corruption & Collapse
5–6
Industrial & Technolithic Wreckage
2. Then roll 1D6 again on the chosen table to determine the specific location and its flavor.
Alternatively, players can choose a narrative layer that suits their factions, models, or terrain setup.
Narrative Layers do not alter rules or objectives unless agreed upon by both players. They are purely
atmospheric—but often influence how players interpret events or roleplay their figures.



52

sections.title: Table A: Sacred & Profaned Sites
sections.content:
Table A: Sacred & Profaned Sites
These are battlegrounds of belief—hallowed ruins, cursed shrines, and relic-laced soil that still echoes with faith,
fear, or fury.
1. Bloomheart Vault
Once a fungal reliquary. Now a breathing ruin. Primary Objectives are pulsing crypt-pods, sealed in
sporelight. Secondary markers are communion points or rotted altars. Everything here lives—some of it
doesn't want to.
2. Moonfall Shrine
An old site of devotion to the shattered moon, scattered with prayer-flags and charred votive pits. Objectives
are memory-altars. Every faction claims it once belonged to them.
3. Saint's Spinefield
A martyred body's vertebrae arches from the ground like a cathedral. Primary Objectives are bone-altars.
Secondary are nerve-beacons or organ shrines. Even the wind sounds like whispering prayers.
4. Ember Choir Ruins
Once a Moonfall chapel, now burned and hollow. Objectives lie among charred pillars and scorched censers.
Faith lingers in the ash—but so does something else.
5. Cracked Halo
A divine fragment impacted here generations ago. Lunar shards pulse underfoot. The battlefield is cratered
and humming. Objectives are still warm.
6. Vault of Vultures
An old archive-keep defiled by scavengers. Objectives are shattered data-vaults and bleeding obelisks. Rot
and reverence mix in the dust.



53

sections.title: Table B: Corruption & Collapse
sections.content:
Table B: Corruption & Collapse
These sites are saturated with Bloom, rot, or broken memory. They shift, breathe, and devour. Battlefields that
refuse to stay dead.
1. The Maw Beneath
Fissures in the ground vent Bloomlight and fungal spores. Objectives are rupture points. The land groans.
Sometimes, it answers.
2. The Sinking Front
Trenchworks drowned in rot and silence. Objectives lie half-submerged in waterlogged soil. Footing is
treacherous. So is memory.
3. Carrion Cradle
The corpse of a crashed relic-engine spills sanctified tissue into the ground. Primary Objectives are
graft-pods. The smell of sacred oil and wet iron never fades.
4. Everbled Crossing
A site soaked in centuries of blood. Nothing grows. Objectives are grave-posts and marrow shrines. Even the
rain feels hostile.
5. Mired Hollow
Once a fortified keep, now drowned in moss and regret. Objectives lie sunken and half-forgotten. The trees
hum with old warnings.
6. Pale Orchard
A twisted grove, blooming with impossible fruit. Objectives hang from crooked trees and fruit-stained
altars. Every root remembers joy—and mocks it.




54

sections.title: Table C: Industrial & Technolithic Wreckage
sections.content:
Table C: Industrial & Technolithic Wreckage
Remnants of the machine cults and shattered sciences that once tried to bind the world. These sites thrum with
static, timing, and rusted memory.
1. Ashen Convoy
A Verdigrave caravan lost mid-transfer. Objectives are fallen crates, ritual rigs, and lockboxes. Looters come
like flies. So do worse things.
2. Hollow Outpost Sigma
An Orrery telemetry tower flickers back to life. Objectives are signal pylons and power anchors. The
battlefield is shaped by fractured grids and angular ruin.
3. Lantern Verge
A border-watching outpost, once aglow with moonfire. Objectives are beacon towers and oathstones. Some
say relighting the lanterns will draw divine attention. Not all believe it's worth the risk.
4. Filament Spiral
Invisible strands of filament rise from beneath the dirt. Objectives are magnetic pylons and data-nodes. The
land sings in codes no one remembers how to read.
5. Throat of Echoes
A shattered canyon where sound fractures and dies. Objectives are resonant spires. Speech here is wrong.
Orders echo back rewritten.
6. Gloamfang Dredge
A dried-out fungal dredging field, abandoned after the Gloam Exodus. Objectives are dredge sieves and
rusted pumps. The air is dusty with rot. Nothing has grown right here since.

55

The players agree to use a 3' × 3' board. They populate it with ruins, fungal clusters, barricades, and

They roll another 1D6 to select a mission from that group: 4, resulting in the mission
